page.title: 12Wool Village...1940 to 1942
page.content: In May 1940 my husband was stationed at Bovington Camp and I came to Wool to be with him. We rented a bed-sit in a converted wooden shed at The Poplars in Spring Street. In April 1941 there were some bombs dropped behind the Dorchester Road, killing a lady in Bailey's Drove and damaging bungalows.There were craters left in the field behind. All the traffic to Bovington had to go over the ancient Wool Bridge,as there was no other road then.The stonework of the bridge was being damaged by Tanks so the stones were removed into a field nearby and replaced by metal bars.They were numbered as they were removed so that it was possible after the war to rebuild the stone wall just as it was before.This was arranged by Mr.Hyde of Manor Farm. We left Wool in 1942 and returned in 1945.(D.Angus)
